playbooks/zuul/run-production-playbook.y.message:
I think this is tricky because we do have relationships between playbooks that we want one to succeed on all hosts before proceeding to the next. For example I think the gitea lb, gitea and gerrit servers, and manage-projects playbooks all potentially have interactions where early bail out is desireable. In the case of base failing to update iptables that could also cause subsequent service updates to fail.

Maybe we should make this an optional behavior then only enable it on things like base which have very broad reach? While I used the iptables example above I Think that is also an easy error to deal with so not super concerned about base running "ok" if there are unreachable servers.

This is going to be interesting because this is going to attempt to load all of keystone's subsystems. When this happens, the configuration object needs to point to the right key repository for fernet tokens and fernet receipts. If that directory doesn't exist, keystone fails to start.

In summary, we need the config_fixture object set up as well as the key repository fixtures *before* we can call this.

The tricky part with that is the KeyRepository fixture currently requires the config_fixture to be passed in. I'm not sure how we can do that if we specify everything in `resources` to denote the dependency.

This is not quite right.  For the N3000 there is some special handling required for root-key and functional bitstreams.  Only one *root-key* bitstream can ever be written to an N3000, so having more than one such bitstream be active doesn't make sense. Applying a *functional* bitstream will *remove* all other functional bitstreams for that FPGA PCI vendor/device.  There can be multiple *key-revocation* bitstreams active.

We can probably keep the implementation N3000-specific for now, but eventually we may need to abstract this further to allow for device-specific logic around how to handle different images being applied at the same time.
I don't think this is accurate...it's possible we removed one applied image but there are others remaining.  We can only set "False" if there are no images waiting to be updated for this hardware.

For alarm clear/raise, I can see it being done here if it can be atomically determined and its not tied to a state managed by the conductor. For some operations (e.g. asynchronous ones), the api could set the initiating state based upon system db view (after acknowledgement from conductor). For 'needs_firmware_update', thus I can see api setting True, however, questioning whether the api should be setting the 'needs_firmware_update' to False; or only have that cleared by conductor on transition to DEVICE_IMAGE_UPDATE_COMPLETED or no such device image upgrade state in progress.
The "device firmware update in progress" alarm should be raised in host_device_image_update() in the conductor when the conductor triggers the actual firmware update.
Generally, updates for firmware upgrade state should be responsibility of the conductor.
See the new changes in modify_flags()

 > we won't lose any status changes.

Actually, I take that back.  We said in the HLD that the "remove" is allowed to proceed even if we were in the middle of doing the device image update.  But we do need to ensure we avoid races in setting/clearing the "device image update in progress" alarm.

Why is that, given that it's going to be processed in an async way either way?

To add some context to the discussion, we're also going to need to raise a "device firmware update in progress" alarm somewhere around line 291.  Would you want that done from the conductor as well?

Then somewhere around line 298 we'll need to clear the "device firmware update in progress" alarm if there are no pending or in-progress device image updates and no host has the "reboot needed" DB flag set.  Should that also be in the conductor?

If we "apply" an image, we will raise the "device firmware update in progress" alarm and set the status for affected devices to DEVICE_IMAGE_UPDATE_PENDING.

Now suppose we immediately "remove" that image.  We need to undo everything that has been done.

Now for safety, we should really have a DB function that says "update the status to X iff the status is currently Y".  That way if the "remove" races against a host-device-image-update operation we won't lose any status changes.

def verify_base_size(self, base, size, base_size=0):
        """Check that the base image is not larger than size.
           Since images can't be generally shrunk, enforce this
           constraint taking account of virtual image size.
        """

        # Note(pbrady): The size and min_disk parameters of a glance
        #  image are checked against the instance size before the image
        #  is even downloaded from glance, but currently min_disk is
        #  adjustable and doesn't currently account for virtual disk size,
        #  so we need this extra check here.
        # NOTE(cfb): Having a flavor that sets the root size to 0 and having
        #  nova effectively ignore that size and use the size of the
        #  image is considered a feature at this time, not a bug.

        if size is None:
            return

        if size and not base_size:
            base_size = self.get_disk_size(base)

        if size < base_size:
            LOG.error('%(base)s virtual size %(base_size)s '
                      'larger than flavor root disk size %(size)s',
                      {'base': base,
                       'base_size': base_size,
                       'size': size})
            raise exception.FlavorDiskSmallerThanImage(
                flavor_size=size, image_size=base_size)

goals/proposed/container-images.rst.message: i agree with this

but not with this.

that is one way to achive that for applications or services with no external dependicies, it breaks down when you start looking at distibuted systems which openstack is.

one thing that might be a worthey first step which coudl then lead to a goal like the current one later would be to enable all services withing a project to run in a monoloth executable. e.g. like busybox

in k8s world this is provided by hyperkube.

in nova functional test we create a tests that execute the distibuted componets of nova all in one process.

so if we had a hypernova entrypoint that ran the nova api, conductor, compute serivce and schduler all in one process with an sqlight db and the oslo in memory rpc backend we could deploy a fully working nova by starting a singel command


e.g. sudo hypernova --config nova.conf

we could futhter reduse the depencies by not only useing the nova fake driver as teh default removing the need for libvirt or openvswitch.

that said if you wanted to use both you could you jsut need to enable the libvirt virt driver in the nova.conf as normal.



if we did the same thing for neutron cinder cyborg and heat? i think that then allow us to  package and subsequelty run all opentack projects with a singel binay per project with no depency on mysql or rabbit.

then you could have a singel docker file or even a tox env
e.g. tox -e hyper<project> to run the hyperconverd version of the poejct.

i think the tox approch is partically nice as the workflow would basically be

git clone https://portject/url
tox -e hyper<project>

with out having to install anything other then git and tox and maybe the bindeps.

i say maybe the bindeps as if you used the fake driver most if not all the bindeps beyond python should not be needed in novas case.


if the goal is really to provide "an easy way to to get
them up and running,"

i think exploing a hyper<project> or hyperstack binay is a vaild alternitive which would not compete with andy of the existing project.

hyperstack might be over reaching as while im sure we could make it plugable so that you can run all installed opetack service from one projcess if we wanted too like you can do with hypercube outside of demos im not sure you woudl ever want to do that.

that said i dont see why we coudl not create a hyperstack binary that actully did just that if we really wanted too.

all we woudl need to achive that is 1
make sure all serivce can run with 
the oslo messaging fake driver
https://github.com/openstack/oslo.messaging/blob/master/oslo_messaging/_drivers/impl_fake.py

2 ensure that all service can run with sqlight3 as the db backend

Exactly.  We don't want to re-invent the wheel, we don't want to support a whole frame of OS, or build big images.  When using those images, you might have to keep some logic in the base OS (like maybe run libvirt there still), or maybe you'll use the libvirt image provided by Kolla.  That's your choice to make.  This is _literally_ just the equivilant of uploading to pypi

i do think using bindeps more extensivly woudl be a good goal.

i would love if devstack or kolla could realy on bindeps supplying all of the package requirements for a project and only install what is listed in bindeps.

it would also be usefaul for downstream testing as we could use the same mechanisum.

That was why I proposed this as a first step for the containers SIG (which dit not really took off). Lack of time and all that. I think having a consistent bindep usage for all the projects (outside just testing) would be beneficial, as _all_ the deployment projects could simply use that.
Yes, so this brings a benefit of being able to leverage this!

I think it's a good idea to allow building images based upon a specific distro.  We shouldn't be picking and forcing a specific distro on someone that wants to use our official images.   Some people that deploy like ubuntu, others like RH.   The loci requirements wheels should be built by loci when a project does a release anyway.

We just migrated off of kolla to loci images internally at SAP.

Indeed, the common-base does help but it makes the Kolla images very unique to Kolla only and special in their way.  Also, the build tools being inside is something we'd like to avoid from the perspective of making those images lighter.

The thing is I don't want us to focus on providing images for all services alongside a deployment tool for it, the goal is to ship images for OpenStack, nothing more.

The goal here is focusing on using the base Python image provided by DockerHub (library/python) more specifically.  We do not intend to start shipping per-operating-system images.

However, the idea is that the Dockerfile should be easy for a down-stream distro shipper to create a similar Dockerfile as long as it has the same entrypoint (if they want to use debs or rpms).

The problem with the Kolla images is that you can't just do:

  docker build .

That's a problem, the fact that you're asking someone to install a whole bunch of dependnecies that are based on Python which pull other things "just to build an image" does not seem like it's the right way.  The "normal way" that things work is that Dockerfile's live inside the repository, that's the way it works everywhere, let's not be a unicorn..

This doesn't actually cater for standalone, someone can mesh all of these, we may even decide to even make a container-image mode of DevStack, the idea isn't to provide deployment tooling, but just an image.  Think how we upload PyPI images.

I think we will be able to work through theseout, I think the issue of extra plugins in someting that has been actually solved as these images will automatically install everything that's inside extras, the idea is to have one-service-per-container, not launching multiple in a single one.

I don't think that this is an effort that will go in vain, I think this is a net positive, the biggest reason we don't have in-repo Dockerfile's made it seem never 'official', we also didn't have the system that are being used by others like OpenDev.

If we ditch the Dockerfile format makes it even worse, I know we want to build cool things using new tools, but peple want to just run `docker build` .. we can do these other things orthogonally, I agree, but our basic fundamental images should be built as easily as possible

This is true. Kolla relies on common bases to reduce image sizes, but it has all build tools inside the images so it adds bulk. Another pain point is templating of all Dockerfiles - it gets unwieldy at some points.

One point to note is that Kolla does more than OpenStack, delivering all the prereqs as well as helper services. We would gladly benefit from having a coordinated OpenStack way to do OpenStack though.

Another point to note is that Kolla supports multiple distros (CentOS, Ubuntu and Debian). Is this goal only about building upon Ubuntu? It's OK if it is but let's not make it constrain us from supporting other major players.

I generally don't like that we are reinventing the wheel here without adding benefits possible via other means, including marketing ones (as in 'try Kolla for easy to use images'). Based on the keystone PoC above, similar result is obtainable from Kolla by asking for the Keystone image, the location of Keystone sources can be chosen at will so it's a no-brainer. I certainly agree with the paragraph just below - Kolla tooling does not currently use Zuul tooling efficiently. I think we should work for some middle ground here.

Another negative case is that the proposed solution by definition caters only for standalone usecase. The truth is that a typical, traditional OpenStack deployment has several services with similar requirements and having many copies of them is inefficient as well.

Yet another thing to have in mind is that Keystone is actually simple. Consider Nova, Ironic, Neutron or Cinder which consist of multiple services, depending on plugins/backends/drivers which have their reqs etc. It's clumsy the way it is done in Kolla now (where we throw everything at them) but it is important to consider future-wise for any attempt at containerization of something more than basic WSGI services.

My main worry is that we end up with a new way to containerize that will give us a toy experience but no real level of usefulness, i.e. repeat the "success" of LOCI but in a distributed way (so more things to clean afterwards).

Final remarks: I will be doing some writeup on ML later this week (which includes weekend) on how to achieve Kolla way in a less ugly way that might be interesting in scope of this but possibly orthogonal. A part of it is that we should ditch the Dockerfile format which is clumsy for any autogeneration and instead go for more buildah-like approach or just about any other. After all, image is just a packed up directory structure with some metadata.
i think kolla is a strong candiade for this goal honestly and need more discussion before discounting it.
Alll of this should eventually go into bindep (hopefully)

Kolla provides nice images.  The problem is that Kolla has it's own build tools, creates images that are aiming to run multiple services in a single container, that's just not the way to run things in containers.

You've alluded to this a few times but I didn't pick up on it because I thought you had worked on the kolla project previously and so knew otherwise.

Kolla does *not* run multiple services per container (with the exception of the bifrost image, soon may it die).

If that's the premise upon which this goal is based, I'd suggest reevaluating.

In terms of being a tool, kolla is a python package. You pip install it and run 'kolla-build'. You could define your Dockerfile templates in each project separately, and pull them in via 'kolla-build --docker-dir /path/to/keystone/', to build images for a specific project, as I suggest in http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-April/014304.html (at the end).

I don't particularly like this 'write off kolla project in a sentence'.

I agree with many of Radoslaw's points. Kolla is certainly unusual in how it builds images, but its approach does have some advantages.

It supports different distros, meaning you can maintain one base OS image.

It supports building from source or distro packages. The latter making it consumable by Tripleo.

It provides quite a range of drivers & plugins out of the box, and if you need any more (which more often than not you will because Openstack), it has a configuration mechanism to add & remove packages. This seems preferable to maintaining a fork of each project and modifying the dockerfile, or extending the image.

It can build all images in a single command. While the per-repo approach works well for upstream CI, setting up something similar downstream for every project would be a reasonable undertaking. There are various good reasons for wanting to build images locally.

Of course it has disadvantages too, as has been mentioned. In particular the images are large. There is a PoC for using multi-stage builds, which can save some space, but only for source images.

If this effort gets traction, the various hurdles discussed are overcome and we end up with images with equivalent functionality to kolla's, I'd be happy to reduce some maintenance burden.

Ultimately though, I doubt that the inability to run 'docker build .' is really a blocker for many.

Not that I want to make it a competition, but Ceph containers are equally weird: https://github.com/ceph/ceph-container

opendevorg/python-base is based on python:slim - it is 181MB

The point isn't that there's no distro - is that for this context the distro is not the important thing. python-base is an image into which a python application can be installed. the python app is the important thing. Indeed, the app and its depends are pip installed (just like in the gate) - so for those for whom distro specifics are important, these images would not be for them for prod. BUT - they do serve to show a very simple "this image has one and only one python application in it" model.

If people like that but don't like the pip part - or don't like the buster part - making an alternate image of the exact same shape would be a pretty easy. For intsance, if we made openstack/keystone based on python-base, it would be python-base + bindep deps + pip depends. If Red Hat or SuSE like the "this image gives me keystone and only keystone" single-process image model, they could easily make a redhat/keystone or suse/keystone image that also had a keystone executable but with the software installed via rpm. To the consumer of the image, the consumption of it would be identical.

Which is all to say - we've been out of teh "make distro packages" business for about 8 years now. As a result we've been firmly in the "as an upstream we focus on pip and we let the distros focus on doing things that are packaging related as their value add to their customers" Making some simple images that are in that model - with the same tradeoffs as the pip packages we already publish - could be useful to some people.

For the same reasons we do not publish rpms or debs of our software, I don't think we should endeavor to make openstack/keystone:centos and openstack/keystone:opensuse and openstack/keystone:bionic and and and and - because from a single-process container model it does not and should not matter.

Obviously we can also choose to not do that.

> I don't particularly like this 'write off kolla project in a

I think we can both agree that Kolla is not "usual" Docker images.  They're very unusual in terms of nature and size, starting from the build process to their very heavy way of functioning.

 > I agree with many of Radoslaw's points. Kolla is certainly unusual
 > in how it builds images, but its approach does have some
 > advantages.
 > 
 > It supports different distros, meaning you can maintain one base OS
 > image.
 
This is a good feature for Kolla, for those who care about it, they should use Kolla.  These images are going to be:

  FROM python:3

Those will be images that have no specific base distro.

 > It supports building from source or distro packages. The latter
 > making it consumable by Tripleo.
 
I also think this is why Kolla should remain around to do fulfill it's needs, for those who want to build docker images using distro packaging.  We're aiming at shipping the equivalent of pypi wheels.

 > It provides quite a range of drivers & plugins out of the box, and
 > if you need any more (which more often than not you will because
 > Openstack), it has a configuration mechanism to add & remove
 > packages. This seems preferable to maintaining a fork of each
 > project and modifying the dockerfile, or extending the image.
 
However, it's configuration mechanism brings a lot a lot of kolla-isms, and for the most part, people will just run the service as is.  While we have some unicorns, most of our code is just Python code.  You don't need to a lot of black magic.

 > It can build all images in a single command. While the per-repo
 > approach works well for upstream CI, setting up something similar
 > downstream for every project would be a reasonable undertaking.
 > There are various good reasons for wanting to build images locally.
 
I think this is something that is more of a delivery issue.  I will go back and stress my pypi wheels idea, it's up to users to deal with them the way that they want.  If they want to a pre-existing buildset or build infrastructure, Kolla is there.

 > Of course it has disadvantages too, as has been mentioned. In
 > particular the images are large. There is a PoC for using
 > multi-stage builds, which can save some space, but only for source
 > images.
 
Gotcha.  Yes, the images are large and I think mainly the lack of `docker build` means the inheritance of all the openstack-y bits that not everyone might be excited to run locally just to build an image (but there will always be those that will).

 > If this effort gets traction, the various hurdles discussed are
 > overcome and we end up with images with equivalent functionality to
 > kolla's, I'd be happy to reduce some maintenance burden.
 
Absolutely, I think that where we get a lot of benefit in this case is the improvement of 'extras' inside our setup.cfg's, the improvement of our bindep.txt which you could rely on when building your images as well.

 > Ultimately though, I doubt that the inability to run 'docker build
 > .' is really a blocker for many.

I think it is to an extent, the more we simplify things and make them feel like "any other open source projects", the more likely we can increase our adoption.  The more we introduced our own systems onto others, the less likely they'll want to take a bite out of them.

> I have a feeling that you never tried to build an image where each

In this case, similar dealing with OSA, and we disable recommended packages in the base image too when building.

ansible/roles/prometheus/tasks/config.ym.message: Is this task required? L90 uses with_first found.
What should the behaviour be here if I put a file in each directory? I might expect to use both.
I've gone with your suggestion - thanks.

Any time you want an 'override' behaviour for a particular list item it would need to be in a per-host file only. But you could have one item in a global file, and another that varies per-host.

There are probably gotchas with either approach.

Hard to support that with the current implementation of extend lists as you may want to completely override the scrape targets on one particular host. One workaround to prevent duplication would be to symlink files from the less specific directory into the more specific one. 

Another option would be to use a meta-key to do merging on a case by case basis. Here is what that could look like:

  _kolla_ansible_extend_list: ["scrape_config"]

  scape_config:
    - item1

  nested:
    _kolla_ansible_extend_list: ["key1"]
    key1:
      - item1
    key2:
      - item1

The default behaviour would be to replace. The meta-key would be stripped from the final output.

Thoughts anyone?
Could use both paths in a list here? Not sure what find does if paths don't exist.
